Group

A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Order of a group
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
Commutative Ring
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Irreducible element

Let $R$ be an integral domain and $p \in R$ a nonzero nonunit. $p$ is called irreducible if a factorization of type $p=x y$ with $x, y \in R$ implies $x \in R^{*}$ or $y \in R^{*}$. Furthermore, $p$ is called reducible if it is not irreducible.
Irreducible Polynomial
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.
Prime subfield of a Field
The unique smallest subfield $P$ of a field $K$, given by the intersection of all subfields in $K$, is referred to as the prime (sub)field in $K$.
Integral Ring Homomorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.
Noetherian ring

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
Cycle

A permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$ is called a cycle if there exist distinct elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}$ in $\{1, \ldots, n\}, r \geq 2$, such that $\pi(x_{i}) = x_{i+1}$ for $1 \leq i < r$, $\pi(x_{r}) = x_{1}$, and $\pi(x) = x$ for $x \in \{1, \ldots, n\} - \{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: The concept of a 'Group' (ID: 0) generalizes the concept of the 'Order of a group' (ID: 1) because the order of a group is a property derived from the definition of a group itself, specifically relating to the number of elements in the group.
